title: Facebook labeling fake posts more clearly in effort to prevent election meddling in 2020 elections
text:
Facebook have announced several new steps to combat misinformation and voter suppression ahead of the upcoming US presidential election in 2020.

On Monday, the social network said it will attempt to increase transparency by adding more information about owners of Facebook pages so users can better understand who is behind a page's content.

This initiative will be coupled with what the platform is calling a 'spend tracker' for US politicians that helps shed light on who is funding political advertising.

Scroll down for video.

Facebook and Instagram will attempt to tighten their grip on foreign actors using the platforms to meddle in US elections via several new tools

The company said it would also start labeling state-controlled media on its page and in the site's ad library.

This measure comes on the heels of Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg impugning the company's Chinese competitor, Tik Tok, for state censorship.

Facebook, Twitter and YouTube all recently came under scrutiny after showing ads from Chinese state-controlled media that criticized Hong Kong protesters.

New measures will also see Facebook start labeling content that independent fact-checkers have marked as false both on Facebook and its sister-site Instagram more prominently.

The social media giant has come under fire in recent weeks over its policy of exempting ads run by politicians from fact-checking, drawing ire from Democratic presidential candidates Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg (pictured above) has come under fire from US and European regulators in the past several years amid myriad privacy scandals

Outside of greater transparency for its users, the company said it will also aim to help safeguard the accounts of politicians that use its platform through a program called Facebook Protect.

The program will monitor enrollees more closely, says the company, and all participants will be required to turn on two-factor authentication which greatly reduces the likelihood of an account being compromised.

Increased security measures come at a time when Facebook is under unprecedented pressure from regulators and lawmakers to clean up its platform and mitigate privacy and data abuses.

Many of the changes throughout the last two years were sparked by the Cambridge Analytica scandal in which a political consulting firm abused the private data of more than 80 million Facebook users to help elect President Donald Trump.
